Commitment is about setting the tone for your team, \\n    especially in remote environments.\n# \u301010\u2020ChatGPT codex.txt\u2020file-LeAHlWUTa77fdMPZG8RG5ucI\u3011\nCore Concept: The Three C&#x27;s of Remote Leadership**\\nThe Codex is built around the **Three C&#x27;s**:\\n- **Commitment**: Leaders must be dedicated to the work and the team, showing consistency and leading by example.\\n- **Connection**: Building strong relationships through understanding, empathy, and dialogue.\\n- **Communication**: Mastering all forms of communication\u2014synchronous, asynchronous, verbal, written\u2014while balancing engagement and avoiding micromanagement.\\n\\nThese principles are rooted in **influence** over control, aligning with leadership theories like **Northouse\u2019s Influence Process**.\\n\\n---\\n\\n### **2. Leadership Philosophy**\\nYour philosophy is centered around:\\n- **Mindfulness**: Being present and understanding the individual needs of your team.\\n- **Continuous Improvement**: Not just personal growth but focusing on refining processes, operations, and practices (similar to **Kaizen** or **Agile leadership**).\\n- **Situational Leadership**: Adapting your leadership style to fit each employee&#x27;s needs, whether it&#x27;s more guidance for a newbie or autonomy for a seasoned pro.\\n\\n---\\n\\n### **3. Modules/Lessons Structure**\\nEach lesson of the Codex explores a different aspect of remote leadership:\\n\\n#### **Lesson 1: Commitment \u2013 Leading by Example**\\n- **Holistic Leadership and Mindfulness**: Show commitment by setting an example and practicing mindfulness, not only in big-picture goals but also in everyday operations.\\n- **Influence, Not Control**: True leadership is about guiding your team, not micromanaging. A leader&#x27;s commitment to continuous improvement\u2014both personal and process-based\u2014is essential.\\n\\n#### **Lesson 2: Connection \u2013 Building Relationships Through Mindfulness and Situational Leadership**\\n- **Empathy and Dialogue**: Strong connections are formed through meaningful, mindful conversations. Leaders must be aware of each team member&#x27;s unique needs and challenges.\\n- **Situational Leadership**: Tailor your leadership style based on the development stage of each team member, providing flexibility in guidance and autonomy.\\n\\n#### **Lesson 3: Communication \u2013 Mastering All Forms**\\n- **Adapt Communication**: Balance synchronous and asynchronous communication, ensuring transparency while giving your team the autonomy they need.\\n- **Mindfulness in Communication**: Be mindful of how different communication styles affect your team, using appropriate methods for different situations.\\n\\n---\\n\\n### **4. \\&quot;Bringing It Back to the Mundane\\&quot;**\\nWe introduced the concept of acknowledging the **less glamorous** aspects of remote work, such as family interruptions, noisy environments, or even serious crises (like power outages, geopolitical conflict, or personal tragedies).\\n\\n- **Realities of Remote Work**: Remote leaders need to address both minor distractions (pets, kids) and major disruptions (internet blackouts, safety concerns).\\n- **Response to Crises**: Leadership requires emotional intelligence and the ability to pivot when life disrupts work. Leaders must balance empathy with support while keeping the team focused.\\n- **Life Happens, Mindful Leadership**: Leaders need to acknowledge the reality of remote workspaces and lead with compassion, showing flexibility when life gets in the way.\\n\\n---\\n\\n### **5. Commitment: Leaders must be committed to their role and their team, consistently showing dedication to achieving objectives.\\u003c/p\\u003e\\n    \\u003cp\\u003e2. Connection: Building strong relationships through empathy, dialogue, and mindfulness to foster a sense of trust and belonging.\\u003c/p\\u003e\\n    \\u003cp\\u003e3. Communication: Mastering all forms of communication (synchronous, asynchronous, verbal, written) and balancing engagement without micromanaging.\\u003c/p\\u003e\\n\\n    \\u003ch2\\u003eLeadership Philosophy\\u003c/h2\\u003e\\n    \\u003cp\\u003eThe Remote Leadership Codex is grounded in the philosophy of influence over control, with leaders acting as facilitators who guide their teams toward success.\\u003c/p\\u003e\\n    \\u003cp\\u003eThis philosophy embraces: \\u003c/p\\u003e\\n    \\u003cul\\u003e\\n        \\u003cli\\u003eMindfulness: Leaders should be present and understanding, managing both personal and team-level needs.\\u003c/li\\u003e\\n        \\u003cli\\u003eContinuous Improvement: Leadership is a continuous process of refining operations and workflows to meet team and organizational goals.\\u003c/li\\u003e\\n        \\u003cli\\u003eSituational Leadership: Leaders should adapt their approach to each employee, providing the right level of support and autonomy.\\u003c/li\\u003e\\n    \\u003c/ul\\u003e\\n\\n    \\u003ch2\\u003eModule 1: Commitment \u2013 Leading by Example\\u003c/h2\\u003e\\n    \\u003cp\\u003eThis module highlights the need for leaders to show dedication by leading through action. Trust them to deliver results, and guide them when necessary without micromanaging.\\n     - Encourage collaboration: Foster an environment where team members feel comfortable speaking up, sharing ideas, and collaborating on tasks.\\n\\n### **Engagement Without Surveillance**\\n   - One of the key challenges of remote leadership is staying engaged with your team without making them feel like they\u2019re constantly under scrutiny.\\n   - **Key Points**: \\n     - Find the balance between staying informed and respecting your team\u2019s autonomy.\\n     - Use tools like task management software, but trust your team to handle their responsibilities without requiring constant check-ins.\\n     - Periodically check in on progress, but focus on supporting and unblocking your team rather than controlling every aspect.\\n\\n### Potential Title for the Article:\\n**\u201cThe Remote Leadership Codex: Mastering the Three C&#x27;s of Commitment, Connection, and Communication\u201d**\\n\\nThis framework gives you a solid foundation to build a comprehensive guide or article on **remote leadership**. You could expand each of these sections with practical tips, examples, and real-life anecdotes from your leadership experience. This draft includes suggested further reading and videos.\n\n---\n\n### **Remote Leadership Codex**\n\n#### **Introduction**\nRemote leadership presents unique challenges and opportunities. It requires balancing logistical efficiency with empathetic leadership. The **Remote Leadership Codex** serves as a practical guide for leading remote teams, emphasizing **commitment**, **connection**, and **communication**\u2014the three pillars essential to effective leadership in the virtual workspace.\n\nThis codex is grounded in the philosophy of influence over control, allowing leaders to guide their teams towards success through presence, empathy, and clear communication.\n\n---\n\n### **The Three C&#x27;s of Remote Leadership**\n\n1. **Commitment: Leading by Example**\n   Leadership begins with demonstrating dedication. Remote leaders must commit to their teams, demonstrating accountability and consistency in their actions. Leaders should model the behaviors they expect from their team members, cultivating trust and respect through example.\n\n   - **Key Insights**:\n     - **Influence, Not Control**: Leadership is about guiding and supporting your team, not micromanaging.\n     - **Continuous Improvement**: Leaders should strive for both personal growth and process improvements, similar to principles like Kaizen or Agile methodologies.\n\n   - **Suggested Reading**:\n     - *\u201cLeadership in the Age of Remote Work\u201d* by Nuratri et al., which highlights the importance of performance metrics and balancing leadership actions .\n\n   - **Suggested Videos**:\n     - TED Talk by Simon Sinek: *\u201cWhy Good Leaders Make You Feel Safe\u201d*\n     - YouTube Video: *\u201cRemote Leadership: How to Manage Virtual Teams\u201d* by Udemy\n\n---\n\n2. **Connection: Building Relationships Through Empathy and Dialogue**\n   A remote leader&#x27;s success hinges on their ability to forge strong connections with their team. These connections are built through empathetic leadership, understanding individual needs, and maintaining open, mindful communication.\n\n   - **Key Insights**:\n     - **Empathy**: Strong leadership requires being mindful of your team\u2019s challenges, both professional and personal.\n     - **Situational Leadership**: Tailor your leadership approach to fit the unique needs of each team member. For example, a new employee may need more hands-on support, while a seasoned employee may require more autonomy.\n\n   - **Suggested Reading**:\n     - Terkamo-Moisio et al.\u2019s study on balancing individual and collective interests in remote healthcare leadership .\n\n   - **Suggested Videos**:\n     - TED Talk by Bren\u00e9 Brown: *\u201cThe Power of Vulnerability\u201d*\n     - TEDx Talk: *\u201cThe Art of Empathy: Leadership in the 21st Century\u201d*\n\n---\n\n3. **Communication: Mastering All Forms**\n   Communication in remote teams must be intentional and flexible. Leaders must excel in both synchronous and asynchronous forms, balancing engagement without micromanagement. Leaders should know what\u2019s happening with their team but trust them to deliver results.\n\n   - **Key Insights**:\n     - **Balance Engagement with Trust**: Tools like task management software can help leaders stay informed without micromanaging.\n     - **Mindfulness in Communication**: Be mindful of how your communication style affects your team and adapt accordingly.\n\n   - **Suggested Reading**:\n     - *\u201cManaging and Motivating the Remote Employee Using the Transformational Leadership Model\u201d* by Sinclair et al., which emphasizes the importance of empathy and logistical preparedness  .\n\n   - **Suggested Videos**:\n     - TED Talk by Celeste Headlee: *\u201c10 Ways to Have a Better Conversation\u201d*\n     - YouTube Video: *\u201cThe Remote Leadership Blueprint\u201d* by LinkedIn Learning\n\n---\n\n### **Addressing Remote Work Challenges**\n\n#### **Engagement Without Surveillance**\nRemote leaders face the challenge of staying engaged with their teams without creating an environment of constant oversight. By leveraging tools like task management software, leaders can remain informed without making team members feel scrutinized.\n\n   - **Key Strategies**:\n     - **Periodic Check-ins**: Check in with your team to offer support rather than control.\n     - **Task Autonomy**: Let employees own their tasks while providing guidance when needed.\n\n   - **Suggested Videos**:\n     - TED Talk by David Marquet: *\u201cTurn the Ship Around: Leadership Lessons from a Nuclear Submarine\u201d*\n\n#### **Life Happens: Balancing Empathy with Results**\nLeaders must acknowledge that life can disrupt work, especially in a remote setting. Family interruptions, internet outages, or larger crises like geopolitical conflicts can impact performance. Effective leaders must blend empathy with logistical planning to navigate these disruptions.\n\n   - **Key Insights**:\n     - **Empathy and Flexibility**: Be understanding and flexible when unexpected events occur, but ensure the team remains focused on its objectives.\n     - **Contingency Planning**: Having proactive frameworks in place ensures you are prepared to respond effectively when life\u2019s interruptions occur .\n\n---\n\n### **Further Reading and Resources**\n1. *\u201cTowards Remote Leadership in Health Care: Lessons Learned from an Integrative Review\u201d* - Terkamo-Moisio et al.\n2. *\u201cManaging Remote Teams: Best Practices and Challenges\u201d* - Various authors\n3. *\u201cLeadership in the Age of Remote Work: Best Practices\u201d* - Nuratri et al. \n\n---\n\nThis draft provides a strong foundation for a comprehensive codex, combining practical strategies, leadership philosophies, and useful resources to guide remote leaders. null, "metadata": {}}, "create_time": 1729799962.816626, "update_time": null, "content": {"content_type": "text", "parts": ["In an asynchronous course on Teachable, &quot;interactive&quot; can refer to activities that engage learners actively, even without live sessions. Here are some ways you can make the course interactive while keeping it asynchronous:\n\n1. **Quizzes and Assessments**: Offer periodic quizzes or knowledge checks after key lessons to test understanding. This helps learners apply what they\u2019ve learned in real-time.\n   \n2. **Scenario-based Exercises**: Create case studies or hypothetical leadership scenarios where learners must choose actions or provide written responses on how they\u2019d handle remote leadership challenges. \n\n3. **Discussion Forums**: Set up discussion boards where participants can share experiences, ask questions, and interact with each other based on the course material. Even though it\u2019s asynchronous, learners benefit from peer interaction.\n\n4. **Interactive PDFs or Google Docs**: Include downloadable workbooks with exercises for learners to fill out as they go through the course. They could evaluate their own leadership style or plan remote strategies for their team.\n\n5. **Video Response Prompts**: Include video lectures where, at specific points, learners are asked to pause and reflect or write down their thoughts on what they would do in a situation. However, the functionality depends on the platform or tool you\u2019re using. In most cases, when you click the inline code button:\n\n- It wraps your selected text in a fixed-width font, often within a box or using backticks (`` `code` ``).\n- It\u2019s ideal for short snippets of code, filenames, or commands, and it doesn&#x27;t alter the formatting like normal text editors do.\n\nFor example:\n```\nHere is an example of preformatted code.\n```\n\nIf you&#x27;re referring to pasting code directly into a course platform like Teachable, the editor may handle inline code formatting differently. Some platforms also support block code formatting for larger pieces of code or templates."]}, "status": "finished_successfully","end_turn": true

Here are some content ideas to make the section more interactive and informative:\n\n### **1. Scholarly Journal Article (Deeper Insight)**\n- You could link to or provide summaries of key findings from a scholarly article on remote leadership, highlighting research that supports the benefits of communication strategies, team building, and performance management in remote teams.\n- **Example**: A journal article on the effectiveness of virtual collaboration or performance management metrics in remote teams could solidify the points you&#x27;re making.\n\n### **2. Case Study (Real-World Example)**\n- Provide a case study of an organization that successfully transitioned to remote work, detailing how they used strong leadership to maintain productivity and morale. \n- **Exercise**: Ask learners to reflect on the case study and identify how they could apply similar strategies to their own teams.\n\n### **3. Video (Engagement Boost)**\n- Embed a relevant TED Talk or leadership video. A talk by a respected business leader or an expert on remote work can offer valuable insights while keeping the content engaging.\n- **Example**: Simon Sinek\u2019s talk on leadership or a video on remote team dynamics.\n\n### **4. Reflection Exercise (Personalized Learning)**\n- Ask learners to reflect on their own experiences with remote teams. You could have them answer a few questions:\n  - What communication challenges have they faced?\n  - How have they built (or struggled to build) team cohesion remotely?\n  - What performance management techniques have worked or failed for them?\n\n### **5. Practical Tool (Actionable Value)**\n- Provide a downloadable resource like a template for tracking team performance or a worksheet on how to build virtual team trust.\n- **Example**: A \u201cTeam Collaboration Plan\u201d template that leaders can fill out to outline how they&#x27;ll foster inclusivity, collaboration, and accountability in their remote team.\n\nEach of these adds a different layer of engagement, depending on what type of learners you want to attract. If you&#x27;re looking to emphasize scholarly knowledge, the journal article works well. For more practical, actionable content, the case study, video, or reflection exercise might be more effective. You could also combine a couple of these to offer variety and keep learners engaged."]}, "status": "finished_successfully","end_turn": true

\u301023\u2020About This Project\u3011 \n\nSearch\n\n#  9 TED Talks for leaders managing remote teams\n\nCheck out nine of the best TED Talks on challenges related to remote work and managing remote teams. Improve your communication, fight burnout, and strengthen connections\n\nBy \n\n\u301024\u2020Stephanie Overby\u3011\n\nApril 8, 2020 | %t min read\n\n[Image 0] \n\n386 readers like this. \n\n[Image 1] \n\nAs a recent Time article pointed out: \u201c\u301025\u2020The Coronavirus Outbreak Has Become the World\u2019s Largest Work-From-Home Experiment\u2020time.com\u3011.\u201d The key word: experiment. Many organizations have \u301026\u2020transformed overnight into remote-working organizations\u3011. Such a sudden shift has left many leaders and their teams grappling with the issues that arise when everyone is suddenly dispersed.\n\n[TEP_CALLOUT_TEXT_RIGHT:Leaders are figuring out how to make remote work succeed \u2013 suddenly and en masse.]\n\nWorking from home was already on the rise. A 2018 analysis by\u00a0\u301027\u2020Global Workplace Analytics\u2020globalworkplaceanalytics.com\u3011\u00a0indicated that remote work had grown 173 percent since 2005. Two-thirds of U.S. companies allow employees to work from home, according to a\u00a0\u301028\u20202019 study by TalentLMS\u2020www.talentlms.com\u3011, and 16 percent are fully remote. There\u2019s evidence that\u00a0\u301029\u2020working remotely can be quite effective\u2020www.gallup.com\u3011, for individuals and the organizations in which they work. Done poorly, however, it can leave teams disconnected, disengaged, and dysfunctional.\n\n[ Do your employees feel psychologically safe? Read\u00a0\u301030\u2020Crisis leadership: How to give people psychological safety\u3011. ]\n\n## Remote work and managing remote teams: 9 TED Talks\n\nFiguring out how to make remote work work \u2013 suddenly and en masse \u2013 can be difficult. To help out, we\u2019ve gathered nine of the best TED Talks that address the challenges that arise when leading and working from home.\n\n## 1. \u301031\u2020Why do ambitious women have flat heads?\u2020www.youtube.com\u3011\n\nSpeaker: Dame Stephanie Shirley\n\nThe title of this TED talk may seem to have nothing to do with remote working. However, Dame Stephanie Shirley is something of a flex work pioneer. She founded the female-only software company Freelance Programmers in 1962 as a work-from-home organization in order to attract qualified women developers. Her 2015 talk on the topic encapsulates some of what she learned as she developed then novel remote work and job sharing approaches.\n\n## 2. \u301032\u2020Why working from home is good for business\u2020www.ted.com\u3011\n\nSpeaker: Matt Mullenweg\n\nSure, most of us are being compelled to work and manage from our personal habitats right now. Allow WordPress co-founder Matt Mullenweg to remind us of some of the upsides, like control over your working environment. Mullenweg, whose employees work virtually from 67 countries, eschews the word \u201cremote\u201d, which he says \u201csets up the expectation that some people are essential and some aren\u2019t.\u201d Instead he uses the descriptor \u201cdistributed\u201d. In this talk, Mullenweg argues that the distributed workforce is the most effective way to build a company \u2013 if you approach it consciously. Key takeaways include documenting everything and communicating transparently online.\n\n## 3. \u301033\u202010 ways to have a better conversation\u2020www.ted.com\u3011\n\nSpeaker: Celeste Headlee\n\nWhen face time is replaced by FaceTimes and in-person meetings become Zooms, good communication skills can go out the window. But they\u2019re more important than ever. Journalist and author Celeste Headlee distills the expertise she\u2019s gained from years of interviewing everyone from Nobel Prize winners and billionaires to kindergarten teachers and truck drivers, into 10 rules for better conversations. Some are emerging as especially important for the digital-only workplace \u2013 such as avoiding multi-tasking, listening, and admitting when you don\u2019t know something.\n\n## 4. \u301034\u2020Why being respectful to your coworkers is good for business\u2020www.ted.com\u3011\n\nSpeaker: Christine Porath\n\nThe lack of face-to-face interaction when working digitally can court bad behavior: rudeness, disrespect, dismissiveness, teasing. Management professor Christine Porath studies the cost of incivility. While individual infractions may seem minor, they actually add up \u2013 and detract from the bottom line, according to Porath\u2019s research. Incivility makes people less motivated. Porath found that it caused 66 percent of people to pull back work efforts, 80 percent lost time worrying about incivility, and 12 percent left their job. Using Porath\u2019s numbers, Cisco estimated that incivility was costing them 12 million dollars a year. Conversely, Porath has found that civility has a positive impact. Here she shares her advice on little things you can do to make sure employees are respectful and respected.\n\n## 5. \u301035\u2020How to make work-life balance work\u2020www.ted.com\u3011\n\nSpeaker: Nigel Marsh\n\nThe lines between the professional and personal all but disappear when working from home exclusively. That makes it more important than ever to master a balance between the two. Author and marketer Nigel Marsh argues that no company can create the perfect work-life balance for its employees. Rather it\u2019s up to each individual to design their best days (and he lays out an ideal one, for starters). \u201cBeing more balanced doesn\u2019t mean dramatic upheaval in your life,\u201d he says. \u201cWith the smallest investment in the right places, you can radically transform the quality of your relationships and the quality of your life.\u201d\n\n## 6. \u301036\u2020Want to be more creative? Go for a walk\u2020www.ted.com\u3011\n\nSpeaker: Marily Oppezzo\n\nOne of the things most of us can still do today is take a walk. Good news: Behavioral and learning scientist Marily Oppezzo has found that that a simple stroll can often be all it takes to come up with novel, realistic solutions to a problem. Oppezzo delivers five tips for making your walks creatively productive, including being purposeful by picking a topic to brainstorm about, coming up with as many ideas as possible, and recording them as you go.\n\n## 7. \u301037\u2020Inside the mind of a professional procrastinator\u2020www.ted.com\u3011\n\nSpeaker: Tim Urban\n\nProcrastination thrives in the work-from-home environment. Tim Urban, the writer behind the blog Wait But Why and master procrastinator himself, weaves a quasi-children\u2019s tale to explain the two flavors of this phenomenon (deadline-based and deadline-less). His talk can spark self-awareness for his fellow dawdlers and understanding among those non-sufferers. It\u2019s more than a navel-gazing exercise, though, as Urban urges his audience to think harder about what they\u2019re really procrastinating on before it\u2019s too late.\n\n## 8. \u301038\u2020How burnout makes us less creative\u2020www.ted.com\u3011\n\nSpeaker: Rafaf Hafoush\n\nBurnout is real. And in a remote work environment, particularly one with added non-work stressors and uncertainty, it can be destructive. So-called digital anthropologist Rafaf Hafoush insists that our obsessions with productivity actually makes us less productive. Creativity, she argues, is more cyclical \u2013 and that should serve as the basis for daily planning. Here, Hafoush outlines how to redesign our work days around creativity for increased productivity.\n\n## 9. \u301039\u20205 ways to create stronger connections\u2020www.ted.com\u3011\n\nSpeaker: Robert Reffken\n\nWorking and managing apart from one another can leave individuals feeling unmoored. The secret to connecting in a high-tech world, entrepreneur Robert Reffken says, is doing a few small things the old-fashioned way. Some tips include writing a letter (thanking people for advice, praising a job well done), picking up the phone and actually talking to someone (an employee, a colleague, your boss.) Also, ask interesting and meaningful questions, answer questions honestly, and always go video rather than voice only.\n\n[ Read also:\u00a0\u301040\u20203 mindfulness exercises to try when you feel overwhelmed\u3011. ]\n\nTopics\n\n\u30107\u2020IT Strategy\u3011\n\n\u301041\u2020Leadership\u3011\n\n\u301042\u2020Emotional Intelligence (EQ)\u3011\n\n[Image 2] \n\nStephanie Overby is an award-winning reporter\u00a0and editor with more than twenty years of professional journalism experience. For the last decade, her work has focused on the intersection of business and technology. She lives in Boston, Mass. \n\n\u301024\u2020More about me\u3011\n\n## Related content\n\n\u301043\u2020 \u3011 \n\n\u301043\u2020Reimagining employee retention: 4 tips\u3011\n\n\u301044\u2020 \u3011 \n\n\u301044\u20205 Harvard Business Review articles that will resonate with CIOs right now\u3011\n\n\u301045\u2020 \u3011 \n\n\u301045\u2020Remote work: 3 pros and 3 cons\u3011\n\n## About This Site\n\nThe Enterprisers Project is an online publication and community helping CIOs and IT leaders solve problems.\n\nThe opinions expressed on this website are those of each author, not of the author&#x27;s employer or of Red Hat. \u301046\u2020T", "title": "9 TED Talks for leaders managing remote teams | The Enterprisers Project", "tether_id": null}, "status": "finished_successfully", "end_turn": null, "weight": 0.0, "metadata": {"_cite_metadata": {"citation_format": {"name": "tether_og"}, "metadata_list": [{"type": "webpage", "title": "9 TED Talks for leaders managing remote teams | The Enterprisers Project", "url": "https://enterprisersproject.com/article/2020/4/9-ted-talks-managing-remote-teams", "text": "    * \u301011\u2020HBR Articles\u3011 \n    * \u301012\u2020Research/Reports\u3011 \n    * \u301013\u2020Resources\u3011 \n    * \u301014\u2020Roundtables\u3011 \n    * \u301015\u2020What is Digital Transformation?\u3011 \n    * \u301016\u2020Automation: The IT Leader&#x27;s Guide\u3011 \n    * \u301017\u2020DevOps: The IT Leader&#x27;s Guide\u3011 \n    * \u301018\u2020Hybrid Cloud: The IT Leader&#x27;s Guide\u3011 \n    * \u301019\u2020The Ultimate DevOps Hiring Guide\u3011 \n  * \u301020\u2020What is an Enterpriser?\u3011 \n    * \u301021\u2020Meet the Enterprisers\u3011 \n    * \u301022\u2020Meet the Team\u3011 \n  * \u301023\u2020About This Project\u3011 \n\nSearch\n\n#  9 TED Talks for leaders managing remote teams\n\nCheck out nine of the best TED Talks on challenges related to remote work and managing remote teams. Improve your communication, fight burnout, and strengthen connections\n\nBy \n\n\u301024\u2020Stephanie Overby\u3011\n\nApril 8, 2020 | %t min read\n\n[Image 0] \n\n386 readers like this. \n\n[Image 1] \n\nAs a recent Time article pointed out: \u201c\u301025\u2020The Coronavirus Outbreak Has Become the World\u2019s Largest Work-From-Home Experiment\u2020time.com\u3011.\u201d The key word: experiment. Many organizations have \u301026\u2020transformed overnight into remote-working organizations\u3011. Such a sudden shift has left many leaders and their teams grappling with the issues that arise when everyone is suddenly dispersed.\n\n[TEP_CALLOUT_TEXT_RIGHT:Leaders are figuring out how to make remote work succeed \u2013 suddenly and en masse.]\n\nWorking from home was already on the rise. A 2018 analysis by\u00a0\u301027\u2020Global Workplace Analytics\u2020globalworkplaceanalytics.com\u3011\u00a0indicated that remote work had grown 173 percent since 2005. Two-thirds of U.S. companies allow employees to work from home, according to a\u00a0\u301028\u20202019 study by TalentLMS\u2020www.talentlms.com\u3011, and 16 percent are fully remote. There\u2019s evidence that\u00a0\u301029\u2020working remotely can be quite effective\u2020www.gallup.com\u3011, for individuals and the organizations in which they work. Done poorly, however, it can leave teams disconnected, disengaged, and dysfunctional.\n\n[ Do your employees feel psychologically safe? Read\u00a0\u301030\u2020Crisis leadership: How to give people psychological safety\u3011. ]\n\n## Remote work and managing remote teams: 9 TED Talks\n\nFiguring out how to make remote work work \u2013 suddenly and en masse \u2013 can be difficult. To help out, we\u2019ve gathered nine of the best TED Talks that address the challenges that arise when leading and working from home.\n\n## 1. \u301031\u2020Why do ambitious women have flat heads?\u2020www.youtube.com\u3011\n\nSpeaker: Dame Stephanie Shirley\n\nThe title of this TED talk may seem to have nothing to do with remote working. However, Dame Stephanie Shirley is something of a flex work pioneer. She founded the female-only software company Freelance Programmers in 1962 as a work-from-home organization in order to attract qualified women developers. Her 2015 talk on the topic encapsulates some of what she learned as she developed then novel remote work and job sharing approaches.\n\n## 2. \u301032\u2020Why working from home is good for business\u2020www.ted.com\u3011\n\nSpeaker: Matt Mullenweg\n\nSure, most of us are being compelled to work and manage from our personal habitats right now. Allow WordPress co-founder Matt Mullenweg to remind us of some of the upsides, like control over your working environment. Mullenweg, whose employees work virtually from 67 countries, eschews the word \u201cremote\u201d, which he says \u201csets up the expectation that some people are essential and some aren\u2019t.\u201d Instead he uses the descriptor \u201cdistributed\u201d. In this talk, Mullenweg argues that the distributed workforce is the most effective way to build a company \u2013 if you approach it consciously. Key takeaways include documenting everything and communicating transparently online.\n\n## 3. \u301033\u202010 ways to have a better conversation\u2020www.ted.com\u3011\n\nSpeaker: Celeste Headlee\n\nWhen face time is replaced by FaceTimes and in-person meetings become Zooms, good communication skills can go out the window. But they\u2019re more important than ever. Journalist and author Celeste Headlee distills the expertise she\u2019s gained from years of interviewing everyone from Nobel Prize winners and billionaires to kindergarten teachers and truck drivers, into 10 rules for better conversations. Some are emerging as especially important for the digital-only workplace \u2013 such as avoiding multi-tasking, listening, and admitting when you don\u2019t know something.\n\n## 4. \u301034\u2020Why being respectful to your coworkers is good for business\u2020www.ted.com\u3011\n\nSpeaker: Christine Porath\n\nThe lack of face-to-face interaction when working digitally can court bad behavior: rudeness, disrespect, dismissiveness, teasing. Management professor Christine Porath studies the cost of incivility. While individual infractions may seem minor, they actually add up \u2013 and detract from the bottom line, according to Porath\u2019s research. Incivility makes people less motivated. Porath found that it caused 66 percent of people to pull back work efforts, 80 percent lost time worrying about incivility, and 12 percent left their job. Using Porath\u2019s numbers, Cisco estimated that incivility was costing them 12 million dollars a year. Conversely, Porath has found that civility has a positive impact. Here she shares her advice on little things you can do to make sure employees are respectful and respected.\n\n## 5. \u301035\u2020How to make work-life balance work\u2020www.ted.com\u3011\n\nSpeaker: Nigel Marsh\n\nThe lines between the professional and personal all but disappear when working from home exclusively. That makes it more important than ever to master a balance between the two. Author and marketer Nigel Marsh argues that no company can create the perfect work-life balance for its employees. Rather it\u2019s up to each individual to design their best days (and he lays out an ideal one, for starters). \u201cBeing more balanced doesn\u2019t mean dramatic upheaval in your life,\u201d he says. \u201cWith the smallest investment in the right places, you can radically transform the quality of your relationships and the quality of your life.\u201d\n\n## 6. \u301036\u2020Want to be more creative? Go for a walk\u2020www.ted.com\u3011\n\nSpeaker: Marily Oppezzo\n\nOne of the things most of us can still do today is take a walk. Good news: Behavioral and learning scientist Marily Oppezzo has found that that a simple stroll can often be all it takes to come up with novel, realistic solutions to a problem. Oppezzo delivers five tips for making your walks creatively productive, including being purposeful by picking a topic to brainstorm about, coming up with as many ideas as possible, and recording them as you go.\n\n## 7. \u301037\u2020Inside the mind of a professional procrastinator\u2020www.ted.com\u3011\n\nSpeaker: Tim Urban\n\nProcrastination thrives in the work-from-home environment. Tim Urban, the writer behind the blog Wait But Why and master procrastinator himself, weaves a quasi-children\u2019s tale to explain the two flavors of this phenomenon (deadline-based and deadline-less). His talk can spark self-awareness for his fellow dawdlers and understanding among those non-sufferers. It\u2019s more than a navel-gazing exercise, though, as Urban urges his audience to think harder about what they\u2019re really procrastinating on before it\u2019s too late.\n\n## 8. \u301038\u2020How burnout makes us less creative\u2020www.ted.com\u3011\n\nSpeaker: Rafaf Hafoush\n\nBurnout is real. And in a remote work environment, particularly one with added non-work stressors and uncertainty, it can be destructive. So-called digital anthropologist Rafaf Hafoush insists that our obsessions with productivity actually makes us less productive. Creativity, she argues, is more cyclical \u2013 and that should serve as the basis for daily planning. Here, Hafoush outlines how to redesign our work days around creativity for increased productivity.\n\n## 9. \u301039\u20205 ways to create stronger connections\u2020www.ted.com\u3011\n\nSpeaker: Robert Reffken\n\nWorking and managing apart from one another can leave individuals feeling unmoored. The secret to connecting in a high-tech world, entrepreneur Robert Reffken says, is doing a few small things the old-fashioned way. Some tips include writing a letter (thanking people for advice, praising a job well done), picking up the phone and actually talking to someone (an employee, a colleague, your boss.) Also, ask interesting and meaningful questions, answer questions honestly, and always go video rather than voice only.\n\n[ Read also:\u00a0\u301040\u20203 mindfulness exercises to try when you feel overwhelmed\u3011. ]\n\nTopics\n\n\u30107\u2020IT Strategy\u3011\n\n\u301041\u2020Leadership\u3011\n\n\u301042\u2020Emotional Intelligence (EQ)\u3011\n\n[Image 2] \n\nStephanie Overby is an award-winning reporter\u00a0and editor with more than twenty years of professional journalism experience. For the last decade, her work has focused on the intersection of business and technology. She lives in Boston, Mass. \n\n\u301024\u2020More about me\u3011\n\n## Related content\n\n\u301043\u2020 \u3011 \n\n\u301043\u2020Reimagining employee retention: 4 tips\u3011\n\n\u301044\u2020 \u3011 \n\n\u301044\u20205 Harvard Business Review articles that will resonate with CIOs right now\u3011\n\n\u301045\u2020 \u3011 \n\n\u301045\u2020Remote work: 3 pros and 3 cons\u3011\n\n## About This Site\n\nThe Enterprisers Project is an online publication and community helping CIOs and IT leaders solve problems.\n\nThe opinions expressed on this website are those of each author, not of the author&#x27;s employer or of Red Hat. \u301046\u2020T", "pub_date": null, "extra": null}], "original_query": null}, "command": "mclick", "args": ["[1, 17, 7]"], "status": "finished", "is_complete": true, "message_type": null, "model_slug": "gpt-4o", "default_model_slug": "gpt-4o", "parent_id": "cde2da16-ee79-44ae-9172-340f437d7af0", "request_id": "8d7d05ae1fa33744-MXP", "timestamp_": "absolute"}, "recipient": "all", "channel": null}, "parent": "cde2da16-ee79-44ae-9172-340f437d7af0", "children": ["10ebf342-9418-4c61-a3ad-8ead80a9554e"]}, "10ebf342-9418-4c61-a3ad-8ead80a9554e": { "message": { "author": {"role": "tool", "name": "browser", "metadata": {}}, "create_time": 1729804958.335309, "update_time": null, "content": {"content_type": "tether_quote", "url": "https://management30.com/blog/top-5-ted-talks-on-remote-working/", "domain": "management30.com", "text": "\n    * ##  Practices, Games, and Tools \n\n      * \u301019\u2020Tools and Downloads\u3011\n\nOur popular games, practices, and new tools, many with free downloads available in multiple languages.\n\n      * \u301020\u2020Shop Games &amp; It\u2019s also been a while since we compiled a TED list and so we thought what better time than now to give you some tangible advice about how to be a successful remote worker and team, from people who have lived and breathed it, for years and more recently.\n\n## Here are five excellent TED talks to help you work better remotely:\n\n#1: \u301036\u2020Three Steps to Stop Remote Work Burnout:\u2020www.ted.com\u3011 A short one but an important one. Morra Aarons-Mele, says too much screen time, too many video calls and too few boundaries make working from home hard for all of us. Here is some honest advice on what you can learn from the introverts in your life about protecting your energy and your limits. \n\n#2: \u301037\u2020Work Together Anywhere:\u2020www.ted.com\u3011 In full transparency, Lisette Sutherland was a former Management 3.0 colleague, but we\u2019re putting her talk here because she is one of the pioneers of remote working for teams. Her company, \u301038\u2020Collaboration Superpowers\u3011, began way before remote working was a \u2018thing\u2019, and today she is using years of experience and knowledge, to help teams and individuals navigate the pandemic madness. \n\n#3: \u301039\u2020Remotely Productive: You can work from home:\u2020www.ted.com\u3011 Jay has been programming professionally for over 10 years. Half of that time has been completely remote. Gain insights into the unique challenge that is working so far from your peers.\n\n#4: \u301040\u2020The Surprising Power of Remote Work:\u2020www.ted.com\u3011 Sam shares his adventures living abroad and working remotely to emphasize how choosing less possessions can create a \u301041\u2020happy, rich and fulfilling\u3011 life while having the free time to chase curiosities and potential passions. Exposure to \u201cradically different\u201d ways of living not only gives you more choice and power to create the life you want to live, but also leads to a more \u301042\u2020empathetic and connected world\u3011, he said.\n\n#5: \u301043\u2020Ten Ways to Have Better Conversations:\u2020www.ted.com\u3011 While this talk isn\u2019t specifically focused on remote working, we included it because one of the most important things when remote working, is being able to \u301044\u2020properly communicate\u3011. Celeste Headlee gives an excellent talk about how to have conversations and says that most of us don\u2019t converse very well. \u201cGo out, talk to people, listen to people,\u201d she says. \u201cAnd, most importantly, be prepared to be amazed,\u201d she says.\n\n\u301045\u2020Photo credit Andrea David via Unsplash\u2020unsplash.com\u3011\n\n* * *\n\n\u301046\u2020Next post \u203a\u3011 \n\n\u301047\u2020\u2039 Previous post\u3011 \n\n## Have you already read these?\n\n\u301048\u2020 Remote Team Retrospectives For Happier Teams \u3011 \n\n\u301049\u2020 Management 3.0\u2019s Top Six Remote Working Blogs \u3011 \n\n\u301050\u2020 How Trello Can Help Your Team Self-Organise \u3011 \n\n\u301051\u2020 Self-leadership skills required for a remote team \u3011 \n\n  * \u301052\u2020 \u2020www.linkedin.com\u3011 \n  * \u301053\u2020 \u2020www.facebook.com\u3011 \n  * \u301054\u2020 \u2020www.youtube.com\u3011 \n\nHappiness at your inbox\n\n# Sign Up for our Engaging Newsletter\n\nSign up now and be the", "title": "Top 5 TED Talks on Remote Working | Management 3.0", "tether_id": null}, "status": "finished_successfully", "end_turn": null, "weight": 0.0, "metadata": {"_cite_metadata": {"citation_format": {"name": "tether_og"}, "metadata_list": [{"type": "webpage", "title": "Top 5 TED Talks on Remote Working | Management 3.0", "url": "https://management30.com/blog/top-5-ted-talks-on-remote-working/", "text": "\n    * ##  Practices, Games, and Tools \n\n      * \u301019\u2020Tools and Downloads\u3011\n\nOur popular games, practices, and new tools, many with free downloads available in multiple languages.\n\n      * \u301020\u2020Shop Games &amp; \u301032\u2020Foundation Workshop\u3011 is where your Management 3.0 learning journey truly begins, and you will learn about the principles, pillars and popular practices you can use right away. If you are interested in other options we offer, please check our \u301031\u2020Learning Path\u3011.\n\nTry again\n\nI have not attended any Management 3.0 Workshop yet \n\nMy background is in human resources; I work closely with the HR team \n\n## Our Recommendation Based on Your Answers\n\n\u301033\u2020Agility in HR Workshop by Management 3.0\u3011 is the popular Management 3.0 Foundation Workshop with additional content and ICAgile accreditation targeted for people who work in or closely with human resources.\n\nTry again\n\nMy background is not in human resources. I&#x27;m seeking to improve my ability to lead and manage teams effectively \n\n## Our Recommendation Based on Your Answers \n\nThe \u301032\u2020Foundation Workshop\u3011 is where your Management 3.0 learning journey truly begins, and you will learn about the principles, pillars and popular practices you can use right away.\n\nTry again\n\nI want my company to be trained in Management 3.0 mindset and practices \n\n## Our Recommendation Based on Your Answers \n\nWith our global team, we provide tailor-made programs to enhance mindsets and skills for entire organizations, ensuring your business is future-ready! \u301015\u2020Learn more about our Inhouse Training Programs\u3011.\n\nTry again\n\nI want to teach other people about Management 3.0 \n\nOur company wants to have multiple licenses and sell workshops to companies or offer them publicly \n\n## Our Recommendation Based on Your Answers \n\nOur \u301018\u2020Company License\u3011 gives your learning team, transformation staff and leaders the ability to facilitate the Management 3.0 mindset, practices and official workshops yourselves.\n\nTry again\n\nI am self-employed and I want to become an official Management 3.0 trainer \n\nI have already attended a Management 3.0 Workshop \n\n## Our Recommendation Based on Your Answers \n\nYou sound like a match for our global Facilitator community! \u301012\u2020Get your Management 3.0 Facilitator License now\u3011!\n\nTry again\n\nI have not attended a Management 3.0 Workshop \n\n## Our Recommendation Based on Your Answers \n\nWe have defined certain requirements that you must meet to become a licensed Management 3.0 Facilitator. We offer both workshop-based and practice-based approaches. \u301034\u2020Read more about the requirements\u3011.\n\nTry again\n\nLearn and experiment with Management 3.0 practices \n\nI want to join a safe space with other people and learn with them \n\n## Our Recommendation Based on Your Answers \n\nIn the \u30104\u2020Official Management 3.0 Community\u3011 you can connect with curious and focused like-minded leaders from all over the world to practice, share, and grow!\n\nTry again\n\nI want to download a game in my language \n\n## Our Recommendation Based on Your Answers \n\nOur practical, hands on and \u301019\u2020tangible tools and management games\u3011 are the best way to foster transformational change within teams, companies and even on a personal level.\n\nTry again\n\nby Sam at Management 3.0\n\nIt\u2019s been nearly one year since so much of the world went into some sort of lockdown and a lot of people started \u301035\u2020working remotely\u3011. It\u2019s also been a while since we compiled a TED list and so we thought what better time than now to give you some tangible advice about how to be a successful remote worker and team, from people who have lived and breathed it, for years and more recently.\n\n## Here are five excellent TED talks to help you work better remotely:\n\n#1: \u301036\u2020Three Steps to Stop Remote Work Burnout:\u2020www.ted.com\u3011 A short one but an important one. Morra Aarons-Mele, says too much screen time, too many video calls and too few boundaries make working from home hard for all of us. Here is some honest advice on what you can learn from the introverts in your life about protecting your energy and your limits. \n\n#2: \u301037\u2020Work Together Anywhere:\u2020www.ted.com\u3011 In full transparency, Lisette Sutherland was a former Management 3.0 colleague, but we\u2019re putting her talk here because she is one of the pioneers of remote working for teams. Her company, \u301038\u2020Collaboration Superpowers\u3011, began way before remote working was a \u2018thing\u2019, and today she is using years of experience and knowledge, to help teams and individuals navigate the pandemic madness. \n\n#3: \u301039\u2020Remotely Productive: You can work from home:\u2020www.ted.com\u3011 Jay has been programming professionally for over 10 years. Half of that time has been completely remote. Gain insights into the unique challenge that is working so far from your peers.\n\n#4: \u301040\u2020The Surprising Power of Remote Work:\u2020www.ted.com\u3011 Sam shares his adventures living abroad and working remotely to emphasize how choosing less possessions can create a \u301041\u2020happy, rich and fulfilling\u3011 life while having the free time to chase curiosities and potential passions. Exposure to \u201cradically different\u201d ways of living not only gives you more choice and power to create the life you want to live, but also leads to a more \u301042\u2020empathetic and connected world\u3011, he said.\n\n#5: \u301043\u2020Ten Ways to Have Better Conversations:\u2020www.ted.com\u3011 While this talk isn\u2019t specifically focused on remote working, we included it because one of the most important things when remote working, is being able to \u301044\u2020properly communicate\u3011. Celeste Headlee gives an excellent talk about how to have conversations and says that most of us don\u2019t converse very well. \u201cGo out, talk to people, listen to people,\u201d she says. \u201cAnd, most importantly, be prepared to be amazed,\u201d she says.\n\n\u301045\u2020Photo credit Andrea David via Unsplash\u2020unsplash.com\u3011\n\n* * *\n\n\u301046\u2020Next post \u203a\u3011 \n\n\u301047\u2020\u2039 Previous post\u3011 \n\n## Have you already read these?\n\n\u301048\u2020 Remote Team Retrospectives For Happier Teams \u3011 \n\n\u301049\u2020 Management 3.0\u2019s Top Six Remote Working Blogs \u3011 \n\n\u301050\u2020 How Trello Can Help Your Team Self-Organise \u3011 \n\n\u301051\u2020 Self-leadership skills required for a remote team \u3011 \n\n  * \u301052\u2020 \u2020www.linkedin.com\u3011 \n  * \u301053\u2020 \u2020www.facebook.com\u3011 \n  * \u301054\u2020 \u2020www.youtube.com\u3011 \n\nHappiness at your inbox\n\n# Sign Up for our Engaging Newsletter\n\nSign up now and be the", "pub_date": null, "extra": null}], "original_query": null}, "command": "mclick", "args": ["[1, 17, 7]"], "status": "finished", "is_complete": true, "message_type": null, "model_slug": "gpt-4o", "default_model_slug": "gpt-4o", "parent_id": "97b69cb5-1ac6-4795-8846-4a5720d8483f", "request_id": "8d7d05ae1fa33744-MXP", "timestamp_": "absolute"}, "recipient": "all", "channel": null}, "parent": "97b69cb5-1ac6-4795-8846-4a5720d8483f", "children": ["c49dc14d-288e-40b0-a946-6a43e227093d"]}, "c49dc14d-288e-40b0-a946-6a43e227093d": { "message": { "author": {"role": "assistant", "name": null, "metadata": {}}, "create_time": 1729804958.335385, "update_time": null, "content": {"content_type": "text", "parts": ["For the **Benefits of Remote Leadership Codex** section, embedding a TED Talk or video is a great way to engage learners and emphasize key points. Here are a few recommendations that align well with your course&#x27;s focus on leadership, communication, and managing remote teams:\n\n1. **&quot;Why Working from Home is Good for Business&quot; by Matt Mullenweg**  \n   This talk is perfect for highlighting the benefits of remote work, including productivity and team dynamics. Mullenweg, the co-founder of WordPress, explains how his team operates across 67 countries and why transparency and communication are critical for remote teams.\n\n2. **&quot;Three Steps to Stop Remote Work Burnout&quot; by Morra Aarons-Mele**  \n   This video addresses remote work challenges such as burnout and provides practical advice for leaders on managing energy, boundaries, and team well-being.\n\n3. **&quot;Ten Ways to Have Better Conversations&quot; by Celeste Headlee**  \n   While not specific to remote work, this talk is great for reinforcing the importance of communication skills, which are crucial for effective virtual leadership. It offers practical tips on how to communicate better in all settings, including remote environments.\n\nThese videos would support your section on the benefits of remote leadership by offering real-world examples and reinforcing the key points of communication and team management\u3010127\u2020source\u3011\u3010128\u2020source\u3011."]}, "status": "finished_successfully","end_turn": true
, "weight": 1.0, "metadata": {"citations": [{"start_ix": 1366, "end_ix": 1378, "citation_format_type": "tether_og", "metadata": {"type": "webpage", "title": "9 TED Talks for leaders managing remote teams | The Enterprisers Project", "url": "https://enterprisersproject.com/article/2020/4/9-ted-talks-managing-remote-teams", "text": "    * \u301011\u2020HBR Articles\u3011 \n    * \u301012\u2020Research/Reports\u3011 \n    * \u301013\u2020Resources\u3011 \n    * \u301014\u2020Roundtables\u3011 \n    * \u301015\u2020What is Digital Transformation?\u3011 \n    * \u301016\u2020Automation: The IT Leader&#x27;s Guide\u3011 \n    * \u301017\u2020DevOps: The IT Leader&#x27;s Guide\u3011 \n    * \u301018\u2020Hybrid Cloud: The IT Leader&#x27;s Guide\u3011 \n    * \u301019\u2020The Ultimate DevOps Hiring Guide\u3011 \n  * \u301020\u2020What is an Enterpriser?\u3011 \n    * \u301021\u2020Meet the Enterprisers\u3011 \n    * \u301022\u2020Meet the Team\u3011 \n  * \u301023\u2020About This Project\u3011 \n\nSearch\n\n#  9 TED Talks for leaders managing remote teams\n\nCheck out nine of the best TED Talks on challenges related to remote work and managing remote teams. Improve your communication, fight burnout, and strengthen connections\n\nBy \n\n\u301024\u2020Stephanie Overby\u3011\n\nApril 8, 2020 | %t min read\n\n[Image 0] \n\n386 readers like this. \n\n[Image 1] \n\nAs a recent Time article pointed out: \u201c\u301025\u2020The Coronavirus Outbreak Has Become the World\u2019s Largest Work-From-Home Experiment\u2020time.com\u3011.\u201d The key word: experiment. Many organizations have \u301026\u2020transformed overnight into remote-working organizations\u3011. Such a sudden shift has left many leaders and their teams grappling with the issues that arise when everyone is suddenly dispersed.\n\n[TEP_CALLOUT_TEXT_RIGHT:Leaders are figuring out how to make remote work succeed \u2013 suddenly and en masse.]\n\nWorking from home was already on the rise. A 2018 analysis by\u00a0\u301027\u2020Global Workplace Analytics\u2020globalworkplaceanalytics.com\u3011\u00a0indicated that remote work had grown 173 percent since 2005. Two-thirds of U.S. companies allow employees to work from home, according to a\u00a0\u301028\u20202019 study by TalentLMS\u2020www.talentlms.com\u3011, and 16 percent are fully remote. There\u2019s evidence that\u00a0\u301029\u2020working remotely can be quite effective\u2020www.gallup.com\u3011, for individuals and the organizations in which they work. Done poorly, however, it can leave teams disconnected, disengaged, and dysfunctional.\n\n[ Do your employees feel psychologically safe? Read\u00a0\u301030\u2020Crisis leadership: How to give people psychological safety\u3011. ]\n\n## Remote work and managing remote teams: 9 TED Talks\n\nFiguring out how to make remote work work \u2013 suddenly and en masse \u2013 can be difficult. To help out, we\u2019ve gathered nine of the best TED Talks that address the challenges that arise when leading and working from home.\n\n## 1. \u301031\u2020Why do ambitious women have flat heads?\u2020www.youtube.com\u3011\n\nSpeaker: Dame Stephanie Shirley\n\nThe title of this TED talk may seem to have nothing to do with remote working. However, Dame Stephanie Shirley is something of a flex work pioneer. She founded the female-only software company Freelance Programmers in 1962 as a work-from-home organization in order to attract qualified women developers. Her 2015 talk on the topic encapsulates some of what she learned as she developed then novel remote work and job sharing approaches.\n\n## 2. \u301032\u2020Why working from home is good for business\u2020www.ted.com\u3011\n\nSpeaker: Matt Mullenweg\n\nSure, most of us are being compelled to work and manage from our personal habitats right now. Allow WordPress co-founder Matt Mullenweg to remind us of some of the upsides, like control over your working environment. Mullenweg, whose employees work virtually from 67 countries, eschews the word \u201cremote\u201d, which he says \u201csets up the expectation that some people are essential and some aren\u2019t.\u201d Instead he uses the descriptor \u201cdistributed\u201d. In this talk, Mullenweg argues that the distributed workforce is the most effective way to build a company \u2013 if you approach it consciously. Key takeaways include documenting everything and communicating transparently online.\n\n## 3. \u301033\u202010 ways to have a better conversation\u2020www.ted.com\u3011\n\nSpeaker: Celeste Headlee\n\nWhen face time is replaced by FaceTimes and in-person meetings become Zooms, good communication skills can go out the window. But they\u2019re more important than ever. Journalist and author Celeste Headlee distills the expertise she\u2019s gained from years of interviewing everyone from Nobel Prize winners and billionaires to kindergarten teachers and truck drivers, into 10 rules for better conversations. Some are emerging as especially important for the digital-only workplace \u2013 such as avoiding multi-tasking, listening, and admitting when you don\u2019t know something.\n\n## 4. \u301034\u2020Why being respectful to your coworkers is good for business\u2020www.ted.com\u3011\n\nSpeaker: Christine Porath\n\nThe lack of face-to-face interaction when working digitally can court bad behavior: rudeness, disrespect, dismissiveness, teasing. Management professor Christine Porath studies the cost of incivility. While individual infractions may seem minor, they actually add up \u2013 and detract from the bottom line, according to Porath\u2019s research. Incivility makes people less motivated. Porath found that it caused 66 percent of people to pull back work efforts, 80 percent lost time worrying about incivility, and 12 percent left their job. Using Porath\u2019s numbers, Cisco estimated that incivility was costing them 12 million dollars a year. Conversely, Porath has found that civility has a positive impact. Here she shares her advice on little things you can do to make sure employees are respectful and respected.\n\n## 5. \u301035\u2020How to make work-life balance work\u2020www.ted.com\u3011\n\nSpeaker: Nigel Marsh\n\nThe lines between the professional and personal all but disappear when working from home exclusively. That makes it more important than ever to master a balance between the two. Author and marketer Nigel Marsh argues that no company can create the perfect work-life balance for its employees. Rather it\u2019s up to each individual to design their best days (and he lays out an ideal one, for starters). \u201cBeing more balanced doesn\u2019t mean dramatic upheaval in your life,\u201d he says. \u201cWith the smallest investment in the right places, you can radically transform the quality of your relationships and the quality of your life.\u201d\n\n## 6. \u301036\u2020Want to be more creative? Go for a walk\u2020www.ted.com\u3011\n\nSpeaker: Marily Oppezzo\n\nOne of the things most of us can still do today is take a walk. Good news: Behavioral and learning scientist Marily Oppezzo has found that that a simple stroll can often be all it takes to come up with novel, realistic solutions to a problem. Oppezzo delivers five tips for making your walks creatively productive, including being purposeful by picking a topic to brainstorm about, coming up with as many ideas as possible, and recording them as you go.\n\n## 7. \u301037\u2020Inside the mind of a professional procrastinator\u2020www.ted.com\u3011\n\nSpeaker: Tim Urban\n\nProcrastination thrives in the work-from-home environment. Tim Urban, the writer behind the blog Wait But Why and master procrastinator himself, weaves a quasi-children\u2019s tale to explain the two flavors of this phenomenon (deadline-based and deadline-less). His talk can spark self-awareness for his fellow dawdlers and understanding among those non-sufferers. It\u2019s more than a navel-gazing exercise, though, as Urban urges his audience to think harder about what they\u2019re really procrastinating on before it\u2019s too late.\n\n## 8. \u301038\u2020How burnout makes us less creative\u2020www.ted.com\u3011\n\nSpeaker: Rafaf Hafoush\n\nBurnout is real. And in a remote work environment, particularly one with added non-work stressors and uncertainty, it can be destructive. So-called digital anthropologist Rafaf Hafoush insists that our obsessions with productivity actually makes us less productive. Creativity, she argues, is more cyclical \u2013 and that should serve as the basis for daily planning. Here, Hafoush outlines how to redesign our work days around creativity for increased productivity.\n\n## 9. \u301039\u20205 ways to create stronger connections\u2020www.ted.com\u3011\n\nSpeaker: Robert Reffken\n\nWorking and managing apart from one another can leave individuals feeling unmoored. The secret to connecting in a high-tech world, entrepreneur Robert Reffken says, is doing a few small things the old-fashioned way. Some tips include writing a letter (thanking people for advice, praising a job well done), picking up the phone and actually talking to someone (an employee, a colleague, your boss.) Also, ask interesting and meaningful questions, answer questions honestly, and always go video rather than voice only.\n\n[ Read also:\u00a0\u301040\u20203 mindfulness exercises to try when you feel overwhelmed\u3011. ]\n\nTopics\n\n\u30107\u2020IT Strategy\u3011\n\n\u301041\u2020Leadership\u3011\n\n\u301042\u2020Emotional Intelligence (EQ)\u3011\n\n[Image 2] \n\nStephanie Overby is an award-winning reporter\u00a0and editor with more than twenty years of professional journalism experience. For the last decade, her work has focused on the intersection of business and technology. She lives in Boston, Mass. \n\n\u301024\u2020More about me\u3011\n\n## Related content\n\n\u301043\u2020 \u3011 \n\n\u301043\u2020Reimagining employee retention: 4 tips\u3011\n\n\u301044\u2020 \u3011 \n\n\u301044\u20205 Harvard Business Review articles that will resonate with CIOs right now\u3011\n\n\u301045\u2020 \u3011 \n\n\u301045\u2020Remote work: 3 pros and 3 cons\u3011\n\n## About This Site\n\nThe Enterprisers Project is an online publication and community helping CIOs and IT leaders solve problems.\n\nThe opinions expressed on this website are those of each author, not of the author&#x27;s employer or of Red Hat. \u301046\u2020T", "pub_date": null, "extra": {"cited_message_idx": 127, "search_result_idx": null, "evidence_text": "source", "cloud_doc_url": null}}}, {"start_ix": 1378, "end_ix": 1390, "citation_format_type": "tether_og", "metadata": {"type": "webpage", "title": "Top 5 TED Talks on Remote Working | Management 3.0", "url": "https://management30.com/blog/top-5-ted-talks-on-remote-working/", "text": "\n    * ##  Practices, Games, and Tools \n\n      * \u301019\u2020Tools and Downloads\u3011\n\nOur popular games, practices, and new tools, many with free downloads available in multiple languages.\n\n      * \u301020\u2020Shop Games &amp; It\u2019s also been a while since we compiled a TED list and so we thought what better time than now to give you some tangible advice about how to be a successful remote worker and team, from people who have lived and breathed it, for years and more recently.\n\n## Here are five excellent TED talks to help you work better remotely:\n\n#1: \u301036\u2020Three Steps to Stop Remote Work Burnout:\u2020www.ted.com\u3011 A short one but an important one. Morra Aarons-Mele, says too much screen time, too many video calls and too few boundaries make working from home hard for all of us. Here is some honest advice on what you can learn from the introverts in your life about protecting your energy and your limits. \n\n#2: \u301037\u2020Work Together Anywhere:\u2020www.ted.com\u3011 In full transparency, Lisette Sutherland was a former Management 3.0 colleague, but we\u2019re putting her talk here because she is one of the pioneers of remote working for teams. Her company, \u301038\u2020Collaboration Superpowers\u3011, began way before remote working was a \u2018thing\u2019, and today she is using years of experience and knowledge, to help teams and individuals navigate the pandemic madness. \n\n#3: \u301039\u2020Remotely Productive: You can work from home:\u2020www.ted.com\u3011 Jay has been programming professionally for over 10 years. Half of that time has been completely remote. Gain insights into the unique challenge that is working so far from your peers.\n\n#4: \u301040\u2020The Surprising Power of Remote Work:\u2020www.ted.com\u3011 Sam shares his adventures living abroad and working remotely to emphasize how choosing less possessions can create a \u301041\u2020happy, rich and fulfilling\u3011 life while having the free time to chase curiosities and potential passions. Exposure to \u201cradically different\u201d ways of living not only gives you more choice and power to create the life you want to live, but also leads to a more \u301042\u2020empathetic and connected world\u3011, he said.\n\n#5: \u301043\u2020Ten Ways to Have Better Conversations:\u2020www.ted.com\u3011 While this talk isn\u2019t specifically focused on remote working, we included it because one of the most important things when remote working, is being able to \u301044\u2020properly communicate\u3011. Celeste Headlee gives an excellent talk about how to have conversations and says that most of us don\u2019t converse very well. \u201cGo out, talk to people, listen to people,\u201d she says. \u201cAnd, most importantly, be prepared to be amazed,\u201d she says.\n\n\u301045\u2020Photo credit Andrea David via Unsplash\u2020unsplash.com\u3011\n\n* * *\n\n\u301046\u2020Next post \u203a\u3011 \n\n\u301047\u2020\u2039 Previous post\u3011 \n\n## Have you already read these?\n\n\u301048\u2020 Remote Team Retrospectives For Happier Teams \u3011 \n\n\u301049\u2020 Management 3.0\u2019s Top Six Remote Working Blogs \u3011 \n\n\u301050\u2020 How Trello Can Help Your Team Self-Organise \u3011 \n\n\u301051\u2020 Self-leadership skills required for a remote team \u3011 \n\n  * \u301052\u2020 \u2020www.linkedin.com\u3011 \n  * \u301053\u2020 \u2020www.facebook.com\u3011 \n  * \u301054\u2020 \u2020www.youtube.com\u3011 \n\nHappiness at your inbox\n\n# Sign Up for our Engaging Newsletter\n\nSign up now and be the", "pub_date": null, "extra": {"cited_message_idx": 128, "search_result_idx": null, "evidence_text": "source", "cloud_doc_url": null}}}], "content_references": [{"matched_text": "\u3010127\u2020source\u3011", "start_idx": 1366, "end_idx": 1378, "alt": null, "type": "webpage_extended", "title": "9 TED Talks for leaders managing remote teams | The Enterprisers Project", "url": "https://enterprisersproject.com/article/2020/4/9-ted-talks-managing-remote-teams", "pub_date": null, "snippet": "    * \u301011\u2020HBR Articles\u3011 \n    * \u301012\u2020Research/Reports\u3011 \n    * \u301013\u2020Resources\u3011 \n    * \u301014\u2020Roundtables\u3011 \n    * \u301015\u2020What is Digital Transformation?\u3011 \n    * \u301016\u2020Automation: The IT Leader&#x27;s Guide\u3011 \n    * \u301017\u2020DevOps: The IT Leader&#x27;s Guide\u3011 \n    * \u301018\u2020Hybrid Cloud: The IT Leader&#x27;s Guide\u3011 \n    * \u301019\u2020The Ultimate DevOps Hiring Guide\u3011 \n  * \u301020\u2020What is an Enterpriser?\u3011 \n    * \u301021\u2020Meet the Enterprisers\u3011 \n    * \u301022\u2020Meet the Team\u3011 \n  * \u301023\u2020About This Project\u3011 \n\nSearch\n\n#  9 TED Talks for leaders managing remote teams\n\nCheck out nine of the best TED Talks on challenges related to remote work and managing remote teams. Improve your communication, fight burnout, and strengthen connections\n\nBy \n\n\u301024\u2020Stephanie Overby\u3011\n\nApril 8, 2020 | %t min read\n\n[Image 0] \n\n386 readers like this. \n\n[Image 1] \n\nAs a recent Time article pointed out: \u201c\u301025\u2020The Coronavirus Outbreak Has Become the World\u2019s Largest Work-From-Home Experiment\u2020time.com\u3011.\u201d The key word: experiment. Many organizations have \u301026\u2020transformed overnight into remote-working organizations\u3011. Such a sudden shift has left many leaders and their teams grappling with the issues that arise when everyone is suddenly dispersed.\n\n[TEP_CALLOUT_TEXT_RIGHT:Leaders are figuring out how to make remote work succeed \u2013 suddenly and en masse.]\n\nWorking from home was already on the rise. A 2018 analysis by\u00a0\u301027\u2020Global Workplace Analytics\u2020globalworkplaceanalytics.com\u3011\u00a0indicated that remote work had grown 173 percent since 2005. Two-thirds of U.S. companies allow employees to work from home, according to a\u00a0\u301028\u20202019 study by TalentLMS\u2020www.talentlms.com\u3011, and 16 percent are fully remote. There\u2019s evidence that\u00a0\u301029\u2020working remotely can be quite effective\u2020www.gallup.com\u3011, for individuals and the organizations in which they work. Done poorly, however, it can leave teams disconnected, disengaged, and dysfunctional.\n\n[ Do your employees feel psychologically safe? Read\u00a0\u301030\u2020Crisis leadership: How to give people psychological safety\u3011. ]\n\n## Remote work and managing remote teams: 9 TED Talks\n\nFiguring out how to make remote work work \u2013 suddenly and en masse \u2013 can be difficult. To help out, we\u2019ve gathered nine of the best TED Talks that address the challenges that arise when leading and working from home.\n\n## 1. \u301031\u2020Why do ambitious women have flat heads?\u2020www.youtube.com\u3011\n\nSpeaker: Dame Stephanie Shirley\n\nThe title of this TED talk may seem to have nothing to do with remote working. However, Dame Stephanie Shirley is something of a flex work pioneer. She founded the female-only software company Freelance Programmers in 1962 as a work-from-home organization in order to attract qualified women developers. Her 2015 talk on the topic encapsulates some of what she learned as she developed then novel remote work and job sharing approaches.\n\n## 2. \u301032\u2020Why working from home is good for business\u2020www.ted.com\u3011\n\nSpeaker: Matt Mullenweg\n\nSure, most of us are being compelled to work and manage from our personal habitats right now. Allow WordPress co-founder Matt Mullenweg to remind us of some of the upsides, like control over your working environment. Mullenweg, whose employees work virtually from 67 countries, eschews the word \u201cremote\u201d, which he says \u201csets up the expectation that some people are essential and some aren\u2019t.\u201d Instead he uses the descriptor \u201cdistributed\u201d. In this talk, Mullenweg argues that the distributed workforce is the most effective way to build a company \u2013 if you approach it consciously. Key takeaways include documenting everything and communicating transparently online.\n\n## 3. \u301033\u202010 ways to have a better conversation\u2020www.ted.com\u3011\n\nSpeaker: Celeste Headlee\n\nWhen face time is replaced by FaceTimes and in-person meetings become Zooms, good communication skills can go out the window. But they\u2019re more important than ever. Journalist and author Celeste Headlee distills the expertise she\u2019s gained from years of interviewing everyone from Nobel Prize winners and billionaires to kindergarten teachers and truck drivers, into 10 rules for better conversations. Some are emerging as especially important for the digital-only workplace \u2013 such as avoiding multi-tasking, listening, and admitting when you don\u2019t know something.\n\n## 4. \u301034\u2020Why being respectful to your coworkers is good for business\u2020www.ted.com\u3011\n\nSpeaker: Christine Porath\n\nThe lack of face-to-face interaction when working digitally can court bad behavior: rudeness, disrespect, dismissiveness, teasing. Management professor Christine Porath studies the cost of incivility. While individual infractions may seem minor, they actually add up \u2013 and detract from the bottom line, according to Porath\u2019s research. Incivility makes people less motivated. Porath found that it caused 66 percent of people to pull back work efforts, 80 percent lost time worrying about incivility, and 12 percent left their job. Using Porath\u2019s numbers, Cisco estimated that incivility was costing them 12 million dollars a year. Conversely, Porath has found that civility has a positive impact. Here she shares her advice on little things you can do to make sure employees are respectful and respected.\n\n## 5. \u301035\u2020How to make work-life balance work\u2020www.ted.com\u3011\n\nSpeaker: Nigel Marsh\n\nThe lines between the professional and personal all but disappear when working from home exclusively. That makes it more important than ever to master a balance between the two. Author and marketer Nigel Marsh argues that no company can create the perfect work-life balance for its employees. Rather it\u2019s up to each individual to design their best days (and he lays out an ideal one, for starters). \u201cBeing more balanced doesn\u2019t mean dramatic upheaval in your life,\u201d he says. \u201cWith the smallest investment in the right places, you can radically transform the quality of your relationships and the quality of your life.\u201d\n\n## 6. \u301036\u2020Want to be more creative? Go for a walk\u2020www.ted.com\u3011\n\nSpeaker: Marily Oppezzo\n\nOne of the things most of us can still do today is take a walk. Good news: Behavioral and learning scientist Marily Oppezzo has found that that a simple stroll can often be all it takes to come up with novel, realistic solutions to a problem. Oppezzo delivers five tips for making your walks creatively productive, including being purposeful by picking a topic to brainstorm about, coming up with as many ideas as possible, and recording them as you go.\n\n## 7. \u301037\u2020Inside the mind of a professional procrastinator\u2020www.ted.com\u3011\n\nSpeaker: Tim Urban\n\nProcrastination thrives in the work-from-home environment. Tim Urban, the writer behind the blog Wait But Why and master procrastinator himself, weaves a quasi-children\u2019s tale to explain the two flavors of this phenomenon (deadline-based and deadline-less). His talk can spark self-awareness for his fellow dawdlers and understanding among those non-sufferers. It\u2019s more than a navel-gazing exercise, though, as Urban urges his audience to think harder about what they\u2019re really procrastinating on before it\u2019s too late.\n\n## 8. \u301038\u2020How burnout makes us less creative\u2020www.ted.com\u3011\n\nSpeaker: Rafaf Hafoush\n\nBurnout is real. And in a remote work environment, particularly one with added non-work stressors and uncertainty, it can be destructive. So-called digital anthropologist Rafaf Hafoush insists that our obsessions with productivity actually makes us less productive. Creativity, she argues, is more cyclical \u2013 and that should serve as the basis for daily planning. Here, Hafoush outlines how to redesign our work days around creativity for increased productivity.\n\n## 9. \u301039\u20205 ways to create stronger connections\u2020www.ted.com\u3011\n\nSpeaker: Robert Reffken\n\nWorking and managing apart from one another can leave individuals feeling unmoored. The secret to connecting in a high-tech world, entrepreneur Robert Reffken says, is doing a few small things the old-fashioned way. Some tips include writing a letter (thanking people for advice, praising a job well done), picking up the phone and actually talking to someone (an employee, a colleague, your boss.) Also, ask interesting and meaningful questions, answer questions honestly, and always go video rather than voice only.\n\n[ Read also:\u00a0\u301040\u20203 mindfulness exercises to try when you feel overwhelmed\u3011. ]\n\nTopics\n\n\u30107\u2020IT Strategy\u3011\n\n\u301041\u2020Leadership\u3011\n\n\u301042\u2020Emotional Intelligence (EQ)\u3011\n\n[Image 2] \n\nStephanie Overby is an award-winning reporter\u00a0and editor with more than twenty years of professional journalism experience. For the last decade, her work has focused on the intersection of business and technology. She lives in Boston, Mass. \n\n\u301024\u2020More about me\u3011\n\n## Related content\n\n\u301043\u2020 \u3011 \n\n\u301043\u2020Reimagining employee retention: 4 tips\u3011\n\n\u301044\u2020 \u3011 \n\n\u301044\u20205 Harvard Business Review articles that will resonate with CIOs right now\u3011\n\n\u301045\u2020 \u3011 \n\n\u301045\u2020Remote work: 3 pros and 3 cons\u3011\n\n## About This Site\n\nThe Enterprisers Project is an online publication and community helping CIOs and IT leaders solve problems.\n\nThe opinions expressed on this website are those of each author, not of the author&#x27;s employer or of Red Hat. \u301046\u2020T"}, {"matched_text": "\u3010128\u2020source\u3011", "start_idx": 1378, "end_idx": 1390, "alt": null, "type": "webpage_extended", "title": "Top 5 TED Talks on Remote Working | Management 3.0", "url": "https://management30.com/blog/top-5-ted-talks-on-remote-working/", "pub_date": null, "snippet": "\n    * ##  Practices, Games, and Tools \n\n      * \u301019\u2020Tools and Downloads\u3011\n\nOur popular games, practices, and new tools, many with free downloads available in multiple languages.\n\n      * \u301020\u2020Shop Games &amp; It\u2019s also been a while since we compiled a TED list and so we thought what better time than now to give you some tangible advice about how to be a successful remote worker and team, from people who have lived and breathed it, for years and more recently.\n\n## Here are five excellent TED talks to help you work better remotely:\n\n#1: \u301036\u2020Three Steps to Stop Remote Work Burnout:\u2020www.ted.com\u3011 A short one but an important one. Morra Aarons-Mele, says too much screen time, too many video calls and too few boundaries make working from home hard for all of us. Here is some honest advice on what you can learn from the introverts in your life about protecting your energy and your limits. \n\n#2: \u301037\u2020Work Together Anywhere:\u2020www.ted.com\u3011 In full transparency, Lisette Sutherland was a former Management 3.0 colleague, but we\u2019re putting her talk here because she is one of the pioneers of remote working for teams. Her company, \u301038\u2020Collaboration Superpowers\u3011, began way before remote working was a \u2018thing\u2019, and today she is using years of experience and knowledge, to help teams and individuals navigate the pandemic madness. \n\n#3: \u301039\u2020Remotely Productive: You can work from home:\u2020www.ted.com\u3011 Jay has been programming professionally for over 10 years. Half of that time has been completely remote. Gain insights into the unique challenge that is working so far from your peers.\n\n#4: \u301040\u2020The Surprising Power of Remote Work:\u2020www.ted.com\u3011 Sam shares his adventures living abroad and working remotely to emphasize how choosing less possessions can create a \u301041\u2020happy, rich and fulfilling\u3011 life while having the free time to chase curiosities and potential passions. Exposure to \u201cradically different\u201d ways of living not only gives you more choice and power to create the life you want to live, but also leads to a more \u301042\u2020empathetic and connected world\u3011, he said.\n\n#5: \u301043\u2020Ten Ways to Have Better Conversations:\u2020www.ted.com\u3011 While this talk isn\u2019t specifically focused on remote working, we included it because one of the most important things when remote working, is being able to \u301044\u2020properly communicate\u3011. Celeste Headlee gives an excellent talk about how to have conversations and says that most of us don\u2019t converse very well. \u201cGo out, talk to people, listen to people,\u201d she says. \u201cAnd, most importantly, be prepared to be amazed,\u201d she says.\n\n\u301045\u2020Photo credit Andrea David via Unsplash\u2020unsplash.com\u3011\n\n* * *\n\n\u301046\u2020Next post \u203a\u3011 \n\n\u301047\u2020\u2039 Previous post\u3011 \n\n## Have you already read these?\n\n\u301048\u2020 Remote Team Retrospectives For Happier Teams \u3011 \n\n\u301049\u2020 Management 3.0\u2019s Top Six Remote Working Blogs \u3011 \n\n\u301050\u2020 How Trello Can Help Your Team Self-Organise \u3011 \n\n\u301051\u2020 Self-leadership skills required for a remote team \u3011 \n\n  * \u301052\u2020 \u2020www.linkedin.com\u3011 \n  * \u301053\u2020 \u2020www.facebook.com\u3011 \n  * \u301054\u2020 \u2020www.youtube.com\u3011 \n\nHappiness at your inbox\n\n# Sign Up for our Engaging Newsletter\n\nSign up now and be the"}], "gizmo_id": null, "message_type": null, "model_slug": "gpt-4o", "default_model_slug": "gpt-4o", "parent_id": "10ebf342-9418-4c61-a3ad-8ead80a9554e", "finish_details": {"type": "stop", "stop_tokens": [200002]}, "is_complete": true, "request_id": "8d7d05ae1fa33744-MXP", "timestamp_": "absolute"}, "recipient": "all", "channel": null}, "parent": "10ebf342-9418-4c61-a3ad-8ead80a9554e", "children": ["aaa28549-1fe9-45e2-95fe-0877221fb323"]}, "aaa28549-1fe9-45e2-95fe-0877221fb323": { "message": { "author": {"role": "user", "name": null, "metadata": {}}, "create_time": 1729804997.831348, "update_time": null, "content": {"content_type": "text", "parts": ["should i use all or one?
